posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Hey, REV Vortex users and @Greg_Needel, do you have any guides on making shaft supports for the neo vortex cantilever? We're using the integrated pinion, which I think is fantastic, and plan to taper the end to 8mm to accommodate a 608. Is this a good idea?

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: We used the 7 tooth pinion shafts for Vortex motors this year on our elevator gearbox to achieve a 12:1 reduction in a single stage. We did not support the far end of the shafts and encountered no issues, but we do not see a problem with using an 8mm bearing, provided the lathe can machine the hardened steel gear teeth.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Oh, interesting! So, maybe the shaft cantilever isn't always an issue? I'm not sure what the failure mechanism actually is.

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked: If you want additional support, this portion of the gear is 13.75mm for standard FRC bearing. We also now sell a 1" OD 13.75mm ID bearing for some alternative packaging opportunities. Another option could be to use our new REV-21-3199 bearing sized for #10 screws: This would enable you to use the 10-32 tapped hole on the end of the gear and have the screw serve as the axle for the end support.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Note: I really don’t want any additional support, but I’m really wondering if I need it. Imagine that you’ve analyzed the failures reported, so what have you learned? What should I know?

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked: We have not experienced any failures from cantilevering REV-21-6800.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Oh! I won’t worry about it then. Thanks!
We managed to shear the face plate on the vortex once due to cantilever mounting, though that was specifically the 8mm shaft on an mk4i drive.
